functionality.description: The tool compiles and simulates RTL design provided in a Verilog/VHDL file format.
functionality.notes: Functionality of Verilog RTL is verified using testbench. Verilog testbench file describes detailed information about which test vector to apply and how to apply.

options.purpose: Use to increase simulation speed. (May reduce debugging visibility)
options.notes: The tool applies a variety of optimizations: merging processes, pulling constants out of loops, clock suppression, and signal collapsing.

functionality.description: Synthesis is used to derive a gate-level design for the given RTL design. Synthesis involves instantiation of appropriate primitive entities, for example, logic gates and flip-flops, which are in technology libraries.
functionality.notes: Design constraints (timing, area, and power) are also provided by the user.

options.purpose: Use to optimize power and area.
Use to adjust the level of effort towards optimization goal.

functionality.description: Check Verilog RTL file and Verilog netlist file for their logically equivalence

tools.name: Cadence Innovus
tools.notes: Innovus is a new version of Encounter.

functionality.description: Transfer structural design (gate-level netlist) into a layout via placement and routing.

options.purpose: Use to adjust the level of effort towards place and route optimization

functionality.description: Analyzes all possible paths through the circuit.

files.description: Includes modules with input/output list, instantiated modules, wires, registers, always blocks, etc. It must be written as synthesizable Verilog.
files.notes: Hardware Description Languages (HDL) – Verilog and VHDL – are used to describe the structure and behavior using a language standardized by IEEE. As long as the same version of HDL is used, every simulator would produce the same response.

files.description: Includes clock generation, instantiated modules, input stimuli for the instantiated modules, order of execution of input stimuli using delay statements, test cases (with corner cases), etc.
files.notes: Testbench file is not restricted to be synthesizable. Typically testbench file does not contain test cases, but refers to an external file, which contains test vectors and corresponding golden responses.
